issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw:
Not one hour after posting these had a spurious error  sending the first steps in walking.
https://youtu.be/-hzPzGEtqII

It's the same foot steps I have sent 130 times (not exaggerating, I have logs of all of them), and on number 131 it fails.

I have gazebo log and some ros topics but I believe they cannot be used to debug this. We asked 1 month ago to IHMC developers how we could debug this: https://github.com/ihmcrobotics/ihmc_valkyrie_ros/issues/12 and we're still waiting for the tools to do it.

If this happens during the middle of the finals and a team loses it's score "bonus" for having to reset.. Well I don't know what's the point of continuing to participate anymore.


How are the judges going to determine whether an error walking or a shutdown of the controller is due to the team's action or it's a bug in gazebo/IHMC control code. Will it be determined immediately when it happens and communicated to the teams or will it be determined afterwards?

Because if we're short on time and the robot falls towards the end of task 3, if we know the score will be reset for us, we might as well start another run instead of spending 2 hours to complete one or two tasks for a handful of points. But if the score is not reset, those two tasks can be a dozen points.
content.html:
Not one hour after posting these had a spurious error sending the first steps in walking. https://youtu.be/-hzPzGEtqII

It's the same foot steps I have sent 130 times (not exaggerating, I have logs of all of them), and on number 131 it fails.

I have gazebo log and some ros topics but I believe they cannot be used to debug this. We asked 1 month ago to IHMC developers how we could debug this: https://github.com/ihmcrobotics/ihmc_valkyrie_ros/issues/12 and we're still waiting for the tools to do it.

If this happens during the middle of the finals and a team loses it's score "bonus" for having to reset.. Well I don't know what's the point of continuing to participate anymore.

How are the judges going to determine whether an error walking or a shutdown of the controller is due to the team's action or it's a bug in gazebo/IHMC control code. Will it be determined immediately when it happens and communicated to the teams or will it be determined afterwards?

Because if we're short on time and the robot falls towards the end of task 3, if we know the score will be reset for us, we might as well start another run instead of spending 2 hours to complete one or two tasks for a handful of points. But if the score is not reset, those two tasks can be a dozen points.

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw: We're interested in this too. There will be hundreds of runs in the finals and probably there will be cases where the robot falls for reasons out of teams' control. Like the foot glitch in issue #186. And then we will need to know what we need to prove that the error was outside of our code.
content.html: We're interested in this too. There will be hundreds of runs in the finals and probably there will be cases where the robot falls for reasons out of teams' control. Like the foot glitch in issue #186. And then we will need to know what we need to prove that the error was outside of our code.

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw:
In my opinion, given the current state of the ihmc controller, I believe teams should not be punished if the robot falls. Having to reharness, go through the initialization process and start the checkpoint from scratch is quite a penalty, specially if it's not the team's fault that the robot fell.

We have put the walking controller in a continuous integration system and are running thousands of steps each day, the walking is not deterministic at all.
content.html:
In my opinion, given the current state of the ihmc controller, I believe teams should not be punished if the robot falls. Having to reharness, go through the initialization process and start the checkpoint from scratch is quite a penalty, specially if it's not the team's fault that the robot fell.

We have put the walking controller in a continuous integration system and are running thousands of steps each day, the walking is not deterministic at all.

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw:
This snippet from the rules might help:

*If the robot must be reset during a run, for example due to a software process crashing, time continues to accrue and is not reset with the robot. However, runs ended by software process crashes will not count if the crash occurred for reasons outside team control. If this type of event occurs, a team should contact the competition administrators, who will evaluate the situation and reset the competition from the beginning.*
content.html:
This snippet from the rules might help:

If the robot must be reset during a run, for example due to a software process crashing, time continues to accrue and is not reset with the robot. However, runs ended by software process crashes will not count if the crash occurred for reasons outside team control. If this type of event occurs, a team should contact the competition administrators, who will evaluate the situation and reset the competition from the beginning.

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw:
Could you clarify the bit about "from the beginning"? That means task 1 checkpoint 1?

And who and how will determine whether a crash (ie robot falling when walking) is out of the team's control?
Does time spent until this reset count towards the 24h maximum allotted for the 5 runs of the competition?
content.html:
Could you clarify the bit about "from the beginning"? That means task 1 checkpoint 1?

And who and how will determine whether a crash (ie robot falling when walking) is out of the team's control? Does time spent until this reset count towards the 24h maximum allotted for the 5 runs of the competition?

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw:
> 24h maximum allotted for the 5 runs of the competition

I can't find any mention of 24h maximum. Do you mind pointing me to where that info came from?
content.html:
24h maximum allotted for the 5 runs of the competition

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw:
https://ninesights.ninesigma.com/documents/portlet_file_entry/15108047/SRC+Practice+Phase+FAQ_thru+5.15.2017.pdf/197f8d8d-369c-46ee-bda2-92cec2edfc9c

At the 2nd page 2nd question, somewhere else it was also said that if the simulation doesn't go at a higher rt factor this limit could be higher, but it didn't get any more specific.

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw: About controller crashes and misbehaviors, I just checked and the orientation is as stated on the rules: if it happens, "team should contact the competition administrators".
content.html: About controller crashes and misbehaviors, I just checked and the orientation is as stated on the rules: if it happens, "team should contact the competition administrators".

issue.title: Question, the IHMC controller shutting down is considered a competitor fault?

content.raw: The orientation is to contact administrators
